update.description:
Fix for drcsim issue #[318](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/issue/318/laser-scan-timestamp-does-not-make-sense), caused by 2 problems: a) timestamps in Scene are not updated as no pose stamped msgs are received, b) new rendering sensor update strategy. 

The fix modified `~/pose/info` publisher to publish on every iteration so Scene gets timestamps, and added a check in Sensor update to avoid duplicate updates.

Also added a rendering_sensor regression test

Update: added `~/pose/local/info` in addition to `~/pose/info` for local publishing at unthrottled rate
update.title: Fix rendering sensor duplicate timestamps

content.raw: poseLocalPub needs to publish every iteration even if there're no new ModelPoses. The msg it publishes contains the timestamp that is needed by Scene.
content.html: poseLocalPub needs to publish every iteration even if there're no new ModelPoses. The msg it publishes contains the timestamp that is needed by Scene.

content.raw: ya, but since shared memory is also in the roadmap, it would be nice to make use of the mechanism when it's ready.
content.html: ya, but since shared memory is also in the roadmap, it would be nice to make use of the mechanism when it's ready.

content.raw: A new regression test! You're my hero!
content.html: A new regression test! You're my hero!

content.html: Should this code block be wrapped inside the if statement, like the posePub->Publish block?

content.raw: I thought pull request #584 set a cap on the transport buffer size that would prevent accumulating memory. I did a test with pr2, where I zombied gzclient, and the memory remained constant. I may be wrong about this
content.html: I thought pull request #584 set a cap on the transport buffer size that would prevent accumulating memory. I did a test with pr2, where I zombied gzclient, and the memory remained constant. I may be wrong about this

content.raw: the reason for using the timestamp in the pose message is because poses are whats used by the scene to update the rendering, and therefore states the time step of the world which the scene corresponds to. Publishing on a separate topic may not guarantee that the arrival of the msg is in the same update step as the poses.
content.html: the reason for using the timestamp in the pose message is because poses are whats used by the scene to update the rendering, and therefore states the time step of the world which the scene corresponds to. Publishing on a separate topic may not guarantee that the arrival of the msg is in the same update step as the poses.

content.raw: If we need a timestamp sent every iteration, we should create a separate topic that just publishes a timestamp message. I think there might already be such a topic (~/time).
content.html: If we need a timestamp sent every iteration, we should create a separate topic that just publishes a timestamp message. I think there might already be such a topic (~/time).

content.raw: I recall that an unlimited pose publisher is a bad thing. This quickly consumes resources, and makes remote (cloud operation) difficult.
content.html: I recall that an unlimited pose publisher is a bad thing. This quickly consumes resources, and makes remote (cloud operation) difficult.
